document_title: Placenta previa: Classification, symptoms and diagnosis
subsection_content:
Placenta previa (also known as placenta praevia) is a condition in which the placenta attaches to the lower uterine segment and cervix, partially covering or covering the cervix, obstructing the path of the fetus during labor. . In a normal pregnancy, the placenta attaches to the front or back of the base of the uterus. (first)
Based on attachment position, placenta praevia is divided into 4 types:
Low placenta: The edge of the placenta is attached to the lower part of the uterus, not reaching the internal cervix;; Placental adhesion: The edge of the placenta reaches the edge of the internal os of the cervix;; Semi-central placenta previa: The placenta partially covers the internal cervical os;; Central placenta previa: The placenta completely covers the internal cervix, accounting for 20-30% of cases.
subsection_title: nhau tien dao.json. What is placenta praevia?
subsection_data:

In a normal pregnancy, the placenta attaches to the front or back of the base of the uterus. (first)
Based on attachment position, placenta praevia is divided into 4 types:
Low placenta: The edge of the placenta is attached to the lower part of the uterus, not reaching the internal cervix;; Placental adhesion: The edge of the placenta reaches the edge of the internal os of the cervix;; Semi-central placenta previa: The placenta partially covers the internal cervical os;; Central placenta previa: The placenta completely covers the internal cervix, accounting for 20-30% of cases.
